title.narrative: OUTPUT 2.2: Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene (WASH) FACILITIES AND HYGIENEEDUCATION IN SCHOOLS

description.narrative: Output 2.2: An increased number of schools in at least nine disadvantaged counties have gender-sensitive water and sanitation facilities and health and hygiene education, including MHM, which contributes to Access To Quality Learning Opportunities, Learning, Skills, Participation And Engagement, Safe And Equitable Water, Sanitation And Hygiene Services And Practices, Water, Sanitation And Hygiene Systems And Empowerment Of Communities. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Systems Strengthening And Institution Building, Systems Strengthening To Leave No One Behind. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: Outcome 2 - Improved Early Learning and Education: An increased proportion of children aged 0 to 18, especially girls from most disadvantaged counties, informal settlements and those affected by humanitarian crisis, access quality, gender- sensitive Early Child Development (ECD) and education services, with increased transition to secondary education.

related-activity.ref: 2400/A0/06/002 OUTCOME 2: IMPROVED EARLY LEARNING AND EDUCATION

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Output 2.2: An increased number of schools in at least nine disadvantaged counties have gender-sensitive water and sanitationfacilities and health and hygiene education, including MHM

description.narrative: A total of 52,940 children (26,154 girls and 26,786 boys) benefitted from improved access to gender- and disability-sensitive WASH services in 110 schools, against the target of 50 schools, in Kitui and Homa Bay Counties. School Boards of Management (BoMs), teachers and Community Health Volunteers (CHVs) have been trained on the sustainable Operation and Maintenance (O&M) of school WASH facilities and hygiene promotion, including Menstrual Hygiene Management (MHM), among 52,940 (26,154 girls and 26,786 boys) . A national WASH in Schools strategy with a costed action plan has been developed through an extensive consultation process engaging government and sector partners. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:28/12/2021
